required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Improving the Quality of End-of-Life Communication for Patients With Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
clinical_study.official_title: Improving the Quality of End-of-Life Communication for Patients With COPD

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate a multifaceted intervention to improve the quality of end-of-life communication between patients with COPD and their primary care providers using information about patients preferences for end of life care and how to communicate and use this information to activate patients, family members, and healthcare providers.

detailed_description.textblock:
This project builds on previous work that described preferences important to patients at end-of-life and desire for life-sustaining therapy by incorporating these attributes into a multifaceted intervention designed to improve the quality of end-of-life communication.
Our specific aim was to evaluate a multifaceted intervention to improve the quality of end-of-life communication between patients with moderate or severe COPD and their primary care providers. The intervention is based on self-efficacy theory and includes provider education, local champions and role models, determination of patients individual barriers and facilitators regarding communication about end-of-life care, preferences for communication about end-of-life care and preferences for end-of-life care and using this information to activate patients, family members, and healthcare providers.
For both control and intervention patients we collected the following information which was incorporated into a one-page summary report:
1. Preferences about cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and mechanical ventilation
2. Preferences for communication with provider
3. Measure of severity of airflow obstruction
4. Barriers and facilitators to communication
5. Preferences for end-of-life care
The intervention was incorporated into a usual clinic visit. For the upcoming clinic visit, we generated an individualized one-page patient specific feedback form for intervention group patients and providers. Patients and providers in the control group did not receive the form.
The generated one-page feedback form was:
1. Mailed to the patient to share with their surrogate
2. Sent to their provider prior to the clinic visit
3. Provided to the patient prior to their clinic visit
The methods used for this study could be translated into clinic practice and possibly generalized to other chronic life-threatening conditions.

primary_outcome.measure: Effect of Intervention on Quality of Patient Clinician Communication About End-of-Life Care(QOC) Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at enrollment and 2 weeks after targeted clinic visit
primary_outcome.description: The quality of end-of-life communication (QOC) score ranges between 0 and 100, with higher scores indicating better communication between patients and providers.

secondary_outcome.measure: Effect of Intervention on Patient Reported Discussions About Treatment Preferences at Their Last Clinic Visit.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed 2 weeks after targeted clinic visit
secondary_outcome.description: We measured the difference between intervention and control group patients reporting having had a discussion with their clinician about treatment preferences at their last clinic visit.

intervention.description: Intervention patients and clinicians received a one-page patient-specific individualized summary, based on questionnaire responses, to stimulate conversations.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
One or more of the following:
1 Have 3 or more outpatient clinics visits for COPD (ICD-9) in the two years prior to enrollment.
2. Have been hospitalized with a primary discharge diagnosis (ICD-9) for COPD in the two years prior to enrollment.
3. Active use of inhaled beta-agonist and ipratropium bromide (or equivalent in combination inhalers like Combivent) in the 12 months prior to enrollment.
Plus
1. Have a future visit scheduled in one of the eligible primary care or chest clinics; and
2. Have airflow limitation
Exclusion Criteria:
1. If they have cognitive dysfunction, language barriers or severe psychiatric disorder that would preclude them from completing the questionnaires. This was assessed initially by the patients provider and by the research assistant during in-person interviews.
2. The provider taking care of their COPD does not participate.
3. Have a new diagnosis of COPD within the last month.

overall_official.affiliation: VA Puget Sound Health Care System Seattle Division, Seattle, WA

facility.name: VA Puget Sound Health Care System Seattle Division, Seattle, WA

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients gave written informed consent before enrollment.

group.title: Intervention (Audit and Feedback)
group.description: We solicited patients' preferences for health care communication and treatment in order to generate individualized summary reports of patient's preferences. These individualized summaries of patient's preferences regarding communication about end-of-life care and preferences for end-of-life care were used to activate patients, family members, and healthcare providers.

group.title: Control (Usual Care)
group.description: We solicited control patients' preferences but did not deliver study generated summary reports to patients, surrogates or providers.

baseline.population: 42 clinicians were randomized to the intervention group. 50 clinicians were randomized to the control group. 376 patients were enrolled and assigned to their clinician's treatment group.

measure.title: Gender, Customized
measure.description: Patient gender reported as percent. *Total is incorrect due to auto-calculating field.

measure.title: Race/Ethnicity, Customized

measure.description: Patient smoking status reported as percent. *Total is incorrect due to auto-calculating field.

measure.title: Male Clinicians
measure.description: Clinician gender reported as percent. *Total is incorrect due to auto-calculating field.

measure.title: Clinician clinic
measure.description: Clinician clinic reported as percent. *Total is incorrect due to auto-calculating field.

outcome.title: Effect of Intervention on Quality of Patient Clinician Communication About End-of-Life Care(QOC) Scale
outcome.description: The quality of end-of-life communication (QOC) score ranges between 0 and 100, with higher scores indicating better communication between patients and providers.
outcome.time_frame: Measured at enrollment and 2 weeks after targeted clinic visit

measure.title: Effect of Intervention on Quality of Patient Clinician Communication About End-of-Life Care(QOC) Scale
measure.description: The quality of end-of-life communication (QOC) score ranges between 0 and 100, with higher scores indicating better communication between patients and providers.

analysis.groups_desc: Power calculation: With 60 providers in each group, maintaining the probability of a type I error of 0.05, power of 0.90, provider level mean QOC score of 54.5 and provider level standard deviation in QOC score of 12.0, the minimal detectable difference in QOC score would be 7.5.
analysis.p_value_desc: No multiple comparisons, a priori threshold < 0.05
analysis.method_desc: Generalized estimating equations (GEE) regression, clustering for provider.

outcome.title: Effect of Intervention on Patient Reported Discussions About Treatment Preferences at Their Last Clinic Visit.
outcome.description: We measured the difference between intervention and control group patients reporting having had a discussion with their clinician about treatment preferences at their last clinic visit.

measure.title: Effect of Intervention on Patient Reported Discussions About Treatment Preferences at Their Last Clinic Visit.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
